Journal.Title: Bulletin of environmental contamination and toxicology

Article.ArticleTitle: Observational Study of Ground-Level Ozone in the Desert Atmosphere.

AbstractText: Arid lands such as deserts cover more than 35% of the Earth's land surface. Concerns regarding ground-level O<sub>3</sub> pollution have been widely addressed in many regions in China, but the behavior of the O<sub>3</sub> cycles in the desert atmosphere remains poorly understood. An 8-year observation was conducted to investigate the long-term temporal O<sub>3</sub> variations in the atmosphere of the Taklimakan Desert, western China. The results showed that the diurnal and seasonal variations of O<sub>3</sub> were mainly influenced by natural processes such as temperature, leading to a different temporal pattern compared with other Chinese regions under the intensive influence of anthropogenic activities. Moreover, the long-term pattern indicates that there exists decoupling trends of O<sub>3</sub> variations between our study site (i.e., decreasing trend) and the developed regions in China (i.e., increasing trend). Knowledge of the temporal O<sub>3</sub> patterns could therefore provide crucial insights for future effective O<sub>3</sub> control strategies in China.
